text: who lead
where'd your new ideas come from
what lessons can we learn from the past
what happens we run out of oil what

whose responsibility is
who will lead
you
welcome it's wonderful to have all of
you here this morning this is surely the
largest and best group that we have ever
assembled at the Harvard Business School
and it's equally wonderful to be
launching what we anticipate will be two
days of in-depth thought provoking and
interesting conversations with you
little did we imagine two years ago when
we began planning this event where we'd
be this morning and what the world would
look like or that some of our very early
decisions in that process to hold the
summit here on the Harvard Business
School campus and to ground it in
significant and indirect enduring topics
topics like leadership globalization and
the future market capitalism would feel
so important and so relevant this
morning we planned a full agenda for you
in the true harvard business school
spirit we've probably planned a bit more
than any one of us can actually take in
the times call for serious reflection
and for deep inquiry over the weeks and
the months ahead we and I'm using that
term very broadly now to include Wall
Street Main Street government's
corporate executives and yes business
schools we need to look carefully at
what we've done we need to think about
what we could have done it should have
done and we must do moving forward the
right thing what we most urgently need
now is leadership leadership in the
short run and leadership over the longer
term leadership at all levels of
business financial institutions and
government when I think about leadership
and about leadership in the context of
the Harvard Business School I think
about a handful of core principles first
judgment that leads to sound decision
making
also the ability to listen carefully and
to communicate effectively a deep sense
of one's values and ethics and finally
the courage to act based on those values
and those principles
